case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. a firm of manufacturers of perfumery and hair oils at Ratlam

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 373 of 1957 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 373 of 1957. Appeal

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 20, 1955, of the former Madhya Bharat High Court at Indore in Civil Misc. Case No. 40 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 20, 1955, of the former Madhya Bharat High Court at Indore in Civil Misc. Case No.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on May 20, 1959 by KAPUR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. May 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-This

facts.text: Appellant is the Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the Commissioner of Income-tax and the respondents are

facts.text: Respondents are a firm of manufacturers of perfumery and hair oils at Ratlam in Madhya Bharat.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents are a firm of manufacturers of perfumery and hair oils at Ratlam in Madhya Bharat and their goods are sold throughout

facts.text: Madhya Bharat was a Part B State at the relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: At the relevant time Madhya Bharat was a Part B State and the sole question

facts.text: Respondents were assessed for the assessment year 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, a registered firm, were assessed for the assessment year 1950- 51, at the rate or rates applicable to income,

facts.text: Assessed at rates applicable to income arising in Part A States.

anchor.surface_text: 51, at the rate or rates applicable to income, profits and gains arising or accruing in Part A States. The companyrse of their

facts.text: Respondents sent out agents to various parts of India to canvass orders and sometimes took advance payments.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrse of their business was this they sent out agents to various parts of India. They canvassed orders and sometimes took advance payments in full or in part and after deducting their expenses,

facts.text: Agents remitted balance to respondents at Ratlam through Bank drafts etc.

anchor.surface_text: in part and after deducting their expenses, remitted the balance to the respondents at Ratlam through Bank drafts etc. The goods ordered were sent to the customers either by V. P. P. or by rail.

facts.text: Goods sent to customers by V.P.P. or by rail.

anchor.surface_text: The goods ordered were sent to the customers either by V. P. P. or by rail. In the latter case the Railway Receipts in favour of self were sent through a Bank deliverable against payment of the

facts.text: Railway Receipts in favour of self sent through Bank deliverable against payment of Demand Draft drawn on buyers.

anchor.surface_text: rail. In the latter case the Railway Receipts in favour of self were sent through a Bank deliverable against payment of the Demand Draft drawn upon the buyers and sent with the Railway Receipts.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held major quantity of goods supplied to Part A/C States and payments received there.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer held that the major quantity of goods was supplied to the customers in what was Part A C States either by V. P. P. or by rail, the Railway Receipts being in favour of the

facts.text: Assessee's banker was Bank of India Ltd., Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: respondents and payment was received as stated above. The assessees banker was the Bank of India Ltd., Bombay, and the sale proceeds were,

facts.text: ITO assessed on estimated profit of Rs. 1,60,340 on sales of Rs. 5,09,424 without concessional rates.

anchor.surface_text: according to the Income-tax Officer, mainly realised through this Bank. He held that the sales were effected in Part A C States and the payments were also received there. He therefore made the assessment on an estimated profit of Rs. 1,60,340 on sales of Rs. 5,09,424 without allowing any rebate

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner reduced estimated profit by Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: on account of companycessional rates applicable to Part B States. On appeal the Appellate Asstt. Commissioner reduced the estimated profit by Rs. 20,000.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal reduced total income from Part A/C States to Rs. 2,85,376.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal on further appeal reduced the total income from Part A C States to Rs. 2,85,376.

facts.text: Tribunal found income by V.P.P. Rs. 1,23,710 received at Ratlam.

anchor.surface_text: It found that the income received through the Post Office, i.e., by V.P.P. was Rs. 1,23,710 and that received in respect of goods sent by rail

facts.text: Tribunal found income from rail goods Rs. 2,85,376 received at Bombay as sent to assessee's banker there.

anchor.surface_text: was Rs. 2,85,376 making a total of Rs. 4,21,955. It also held that the advances received with orders were income, profits and gains received at Ratlam and number in Part A C States and similarly the price of goods sent by V. P. P. was also money received at Ratlam. In regard to the price received by Bank drafts it held that they were received at Ratlam but were sent to the assessees banker in Bombay for being cashed and therefore they must be taken to have been received in a Part A State. This amount was Rs. 2,85,376.

facts.text: Advances received with orders were held by Tribunal to be received at Ratlam.

anchor.surface_text: It also held that the advances received with orders were income, profits and gains received at Ratlam and number in Part A C States

facts.text: Both assessee and Commissioner applied for reference to High Court under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: Both the assessees and the Commissioner applied for a reference -to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Income- tax Act

facts.text: Two questions referred to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: and following two questions were referred - Q.1 Whether the receipt of sale proceeds at Ratlam  which included the assessees profits  in respect of goods sent by the assessee to customers in Part A or C States by V. P. P. amounted to receipts of income, profits or gains at Ratlam in Part B States? Q. 2. Whether the bank drafts payable in Part A or C States but received at Ratlam and encashed through the assessees bankers at Bombay companystituted receipts in Part A State ?

facts.text: High Court answered both questions in favour of the assessees.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered both these questions in favour of the assessees but gave a certificate

facts.text: High Court gave certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: but gave a certificate and the  1  1952 21 I.T.R. 82. appeal is therefore brought by the Commissioner of Income- tax.

facts.text: Bankers instructed to hand over goods against payment of the enclosed demand draft.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the printed advice sent by the assessee to its bankers in every case that the bankers are to hand over the goods against payment of t he enclosed demand draft.
under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: fall under s. 25 of the Indian Sale of Goods Act which provides- Section 25 1 . Where there is a companytract for the sale of specific goods or where goods are subsequently appropriated to the companytract, the seller may, by the terms of the companytract or appropriation, reserve the right of disposal of the goods until certain companyditions are fulfilled. In such case, numberwithstanding the delivery of the goods to a buyer, or to a carrier or other bailee for the purpose of transmission to the buyer, the property in the goods does number pass to the buyer until the companyditions imposed by the seller are fulfilled.

concepts.interpretation: Seller reserves right of disposal until conditions like payment fulfilled; property does not pass despite delivery to carrier until conditions met; applied to V.P.P. and rail despatches making sale complete at payment place.

concepts.unlisted_description: Reservation of right of disposal of goods

anchor.surface_text: Even a bailment for transmission would fall under s. 25 of the Sale of Goods Act and there is only a companyditional appropriation

concepts.interpretation: Conditional appropriation under section applies to bailment for transmission; goods do not pass until condition (payment) fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 148 of the Indian Contract Act a bailment is delivery of goods by one person to another upon a companytract that they shall, when the purpose is accomplished be returned or otherwise disposed of according to the directions of the person delivering them.

concepts.interpretation: Bailee must follow bailor's directions; here, Post Office as bailee receives price on behalf of seller (bailor) at delivery place.

issues.text: Whether the receipt of sale proceeds at Ratlam which included the assessees profits in respect of goods sent by the assessee to customers in Part A or C States by V. P. P. amounted to receipts of income, profits or gains at Ratlam in Part B States?

anchor.surface_text: Q.1 Whether the receipt of sale proceeds at Ratlam which included the assessees profits in respect of goods sent by the assessee to customers in Part A or C States by V. P. P. amounted to receipts of income, profits or gains at Ratlam in Part B States?

issues.text: Whether the bank drafts payable in Part A or C States but received at Ratlam and encashed through the assessees bankers at Bombay constituted receipts in Part A State ?

anchor.surface_text: Q. 2. Whether the bank drafts payable in Part A or C States but received at Ratlam and encashed through the assessees bankers at Bombay constituted receipts in Part A State ? The High Court answered both these questions in favour of the assessees

issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case the payment received from a buyer by a banker in Part A or C States against delivery of Railway Receipt for goods sent by the seller is payment in these States or in Ratlam which was a Part B State
